awd_titl_txt: CEDAR:  Probing the Upper E-region and Lower F-region Neutral Winds Using Ionospheric Heating
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this proposal is to examine the response of thermospheric neutral winds to space weather. Local winds in the 150-250 km range are very difficult to measure owing to the absence of sustained optical emissions over this altitude range. The PI therefore proposes to artificially stimulate such emissions by directly heating the ionosphere using very high-power, high-frequency radio waves. These emissions will be detected by an  instrument called a Fabry-Perot interferometer (FPI), that characterizes the properties of light emitted by molecules in motion. The heating of the ionosphere will take place at the High frequency Active Auroral Radar Project (HAARP) facility in Alaska. Two FPIs will be located within 320 km from the HAARP facility, in order to resolve the horizontal wind vector. Broader impacts of this proposal include Ph.D. training at UAF, STEM outreach to local schools, and raising the profile of the HAARP heating facility following its transition from military to UAF management.

The specific goals of this project are to 1. Determine winds with high vertical (10 km) and temporal (several minutes) resolution through coordinated FPI and HAARP observing activity 2. Examine altitude and temporal variations in these winds under both artificial (HAARP-induced) and auroral conditions. The intellectual merits of the proposal lie in demonstrating the new wind recovery methods, and in resolving their altitudinal and temporal variability.

por.por_cntn:
Project outcomes

Winds and temperatures in our upper atmosphere have a significant influence on global communications and the operations of satellites. While some altitudes are measured regularly using natural glowing layers and sensitive instruments, called Fabry-Perot Interferometers (FPIs), that can measure motion of those upper altitude layers, there are few natural emissions in a layer from about 130 to 190 km (80 to 120 miles). Ionospheric heaters, like the High-Frequency Active Auroral Research Program (HAARP) in central Alaska, can produce glowing clouds at this altitude range when conditions are correct. This project is intended to see if using FPIs to observe these artificial glowing regions can be used to make useful measurements in this region.

We staged two FPIs at two observatories, at Poker Flat Research Range (PFRR) and Eagle in Alaska, both about 300 km (190 miles) from the HAARP facility. On two occasions the combination of density of charged particles in the upper atmosphere (so called ionosphere) allowed a HAARP spot to be produced, and the weather and FPI operations allowed us to measure its. This shows that with proper planning the light emitted from the spots can be observed. The ideal measurement would have been to see the light from the HAARP spots simultaneously from both observatories, but because of weather and instrument issues, we did not achieve that goal. The two individual observations however provide needed information on whether such a set of observations will indeed provide the proper signal to be able to determine the strength of the winds at these altitudes.

We can confirm this by use of a model that we developed in the last year of the project (when HAARP operations were curtailed due to COVID-19 restrictions). The model can simulate the raw images produced by a FPI for a range of parameters of the light producing region (the HAARP spot, or airglow, or aurora), and parameters of the instrument. It can combine the results from both the HAARP spot and the background natural emission which can then be analyzed using our standard software for the images from the FPI. The model has now been validated with basic data and we are continuing to look at results from the observations we have made and look at a wide range of parameters for what we might expect during an observing campaign. This model will let us design the way we take the data (how often to observe, etc.), and let us predict under what conditions making these observations will result in meaningful results.

This is important since this altitude layer – called the lower thermosphere – is a region where the atmosphere transitions from motion driven predominantly by rapid collisions, to one where collisions are very slow (at high altitudes) which has consequences for changes in density and how quickly the speed and direction of the winds change. It also affects how the charged particles in the ionosphere are distributed which can affect communications and satellite-based navigation.

As HAARP campaigns begin again, the instruments we have configured for this project can still be used to make measurements of the HAARP spot, and the model we have developed can be used to confirm how well we can rely on the measurements we make.
